<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 0 0.05IN 0 0">
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 0 0.05IN 0 0">
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 0 0.05IN 0 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: BOLD 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 6PT 0.05IN 6PT 0">
	Year ended March 31, 2016 (Fiscal 2016) Compared
	to Year Ended March 31, 2015 (Fiscal 2015)
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 6PT 0.05IN 6PT 0">
<I>
	Net Sales
</I>
	- The Company's net sales from continuing
	operations for the year ended March 31, 2016 were $44,568,000, an increase of $6,492,000 or 17.1% as compared to $38,076,000 in
	fiscal 2015. The increase was related to an increase in sales revenues of $53,000 in our plastic segment and an increase of $6,439,000
	in our electronic segment, as compared with the respective net sales from these segments in the prior fiscal year.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 6PT 0.05IN 6PT 0">
	The revenue increase in the plastic segment was due
	to an increase of $2,894,000 in orders from existing customers for printing, office equipment and local sales, offsetting a decrease
	of $2,841,000 in sales orders from existing customers mainly for telephone, medical and other products.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 6PT 0.05IN 6PT 0">
	The revenue increase in the electronic segment was
	mainly due to an increase of $8,858,000 in orders from existing customers for home entertainment products and professional audio
	instruments, offsetting a decrease of $2,535,000 in orders for professional audio equipment from other existing customers. The
	increase in sales orders was mainly attributed to the continued efforts to develop new opportunities and collaborating new products
	with our existing customers.
</P>
<!-- FIELD: PAGE; SEQUENCE: 31; VALUE: 2 -->
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP: 6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 6PT; BORDER-BOTTOM: BLACK 4PT SOLID">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP: 0PT; TEXT-ALIGN: CENTER; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0PT; FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF">
<!-- FIELD: SEQUENCE; TYPE: ARABIC; NAME: PAGENO -->
	31
<!-- FIELD: /SEQUENCE -->
	&nbsp;
</P>
</DIV>
<A NAME="eolPage32"></A>
<DIV STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: ALWAYS; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 6PT">
<P STYLE="MARGIN: 0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
</DIV>
<!-- FIELD: /PAGE -->
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 6PT 0.05IN 6PT 0">
<I>
	Gross Profit
</I>
	- Gross profit from continuing
	operations for the year ended March 31, 2016 was $4,793,000, representing a gross profit margin of 10.8%. This compared with the
	overall gross profit from continuing operations of $4,224,000 and gross profit margin of 11.1% for the year ended March 31, 2015.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 6PT 0.05IN 6PT 0">
	Gross profit in the plastic segment increased by
	$46,000 to $3,381,000 or 17.1% of net sales for the year ended March 31, 2016, as compared to $3,335,000 or 16.9% of net sales,
	for the same period in the prior fiscal year. The increase in gross margin for the plastic segment was mainly due to a decrease
	in factory overheads, as a percentage of net sales, when compared with last fiscal year.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 6PT 0.05IN 6PT 0">
	Gross profit in the electronic segment increased
	by $523,000 to $1,412,000 or 5.7% of net sales for the year ended March 31, 2016, as compared to $889,000 or 4.9% of net sales,
	for the prior fiscal year. The increase in gross margin was mainly attributed to decreases in labor cost and factory overheads,
	offsetting an increase in raw materials cost, as a percentage of sales, when compared with last fiscal year.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 6PT 0.05IN 6PT 0">
<I>
	Selling, general and administrative expenses
</I>
	- SG&amp;A expenses from continuing operations for the year ended March 31, 2016 were $9,119,000 or 20.5% of total net sales from
	continuing operations, as compared to $9,123,000 or 24.0% of total net sales from continuing operations for the year ended March
	31, 2015. Selling, general and administrative expenses decreased by $4,000 in fiscal 2016 compared to fiscal 2015.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 6PT 0.05IN 6PT 0">
	SG&amp;A expenses in the plastic segment decreased
	by $493,000 to $5,307,000 or 26.8% of net sales for the year ended March 31, 2016, compared to $5,800,000 or 29.3% of net sales
	for fiscal 2015. The decrease was primarily related to decreases of $139,000 in stock compensation cost, $41,000 in legal and professional
	fees, $64,000 in local government taxes, $28,000 in traveling expense, as well as $124,000 in selling expense, as compared with
	the same period in the prior fiscal year.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 6PT 0.05IN 6PT 0">
	SG&amp;A expenses in the electronic segment increased
	by $489,000 to $3,812,000 or 15.4% of net sales for the year ended March 31, 2016, compared to $3,323,000 or 18.2% of net sales
	for fiscal 2015. The increase was mainly due to increases of $600,000 in staff costs, offsetting decreases of $60,000 in stock
	compensation cost, $49,000 in local government taxes and $15,000 in utility expense, as well as $29,000 in selling expense, when
	compared to prior fiscal year.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 6PT 0.05IN 6PT 0">
<I>
	Other income/expense, net
</I>
	- Other expense
	from continuing operations was $1,021,000 for the year ended March 31, 2016, as compared to other income from continuing operations
	of $93,000 in prior fiscal year.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 6PT 0.05IN 6PT 0">
	On a segment basis, other expense attributable to
	the plastic segment for the year ended March 31, 2016 was $1,310,000, as compared to other income of $9,000 for prior fiscal year.
	Other expense in fiscal 2016 was mainly due to $600,000 in exchange loss, $426,000 of loss on the disposal of fixed assets and
	a provision of $273,000 for doubtful receivables, as compared to gains on the disposal of fixed assets of $259,000 and of $20,000
	for materials, offsetting an exchange loss of $170,000 and a provision of $98,000 for doubtful receivables during fiscal 2015.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 6PT 0.05IN 6PT 0">
	Other income attributable to the electronic segment
	for the year ended March 31, 2016 was $289,000, as compared with other income of $84,000 for the prior fiscal year. This decrease
	in other income was mainly due to gains of $49,000 from exchange, of $153,000 from sale of materials and others, and of $83,000
	in other income during the year ended March 31, 2016, as compared to a gain of $3,000 on the disposal of fixed assets and income
	of $75,000 from the sale of materials and others in the prior fiscal year.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 6PT 0.05IN 6PT 0">
<I>
	Operating Loss
</I>
	- Operating loss from continuing
	operations was $5,347,000 for the year ended March 31, 2016, as compared to operating loss from continuing operations of $4,806,000
	in prior fiscal year.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 6PT 0.05IN 6PT 0">
	On a segment basis, the operating loss in the plastic
	segment was $3,236,000 in the year ended March 31, 2016, as compared to an operating loss of $2,456,000 in fiscal 2015. The increase
	in operating loss in the plastic segment was mainly due to incurring other expense (net) in fiscal 2016, compared to incurring
	other income in fiscal 2015.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 6PT 0.05IN 6PT 0">
	The electronic segment reported an operating loss
	of $2,111,000 in the year ended March 31, 2016, compared to an operating loss of $2,350,000 in fiscal 2015. The decrease in operating
	loss was largely due to an increase in sales turnover and gross margin as described above.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 6PT 0.05IN 6PT 0">
<I>
	Non-operating income
</I>
	&ndash; Non-operating
	income from continuing operations for the year ended March 31, 2016 was $571,000, as compared to non-operating income from continuing
	operations of $2,553,000 in last fiscal year. The decrease was primarily due to decreases of $2,814,000 on the fair value of marketable
	securities, and of $163,000 in interest income, offsetting increases of $358,000 in dividend income, $424,000 in realized gain
	on sale of marketable securities, and $192,000 in rental income as compared to fiscal 2015.
</P>
<!-- FIELD: PAGE; SEQUENCE: 32; VALUE: 2 -->
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP: 6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 6PT; BORDER-BOTTOM: BLACK 4PT SOLID">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP: 0PT; TEXT-ALIGN: CENTER; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0PT; FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF">
<!-- FIELD: SEQUENCE; TYPE: ARABIC; NAME: PAGENO -->
	32
<!-- FIELD: /SEQUENCE -->
	&nbsp;
</P>
</DIV>
<A NAME="eolPage33"></A>
<DIV STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: ALWAYS; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 6PT">
<P STYLE="MARGIN: 0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
</DIV>
<!-- FIELD: /PAGE -->
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 6PT 0.05IN 6PT 0">
<I>
	Income Taxes
</I>
	&ndash; Income tax from continuing
	operations for the year ended March 31, 2016 was comprised of an income tax expense of $103,000 and a deferred tax provision of
	$55,000, as compared to an income tax expense of $92,000 and a deferred tax provision of $115,000 from continuing operations in
	last fiscal year.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 6PT 0.05IN 6PT 0">
	On a segment basis, there was income tax expense
	of $50,000 and a deferred tax provision of $54,000 in the plastic segment for the year ended March 31, 2016, as compared to income
	tax expense of $49,000 and a deferred tax provision of $115,000 during the last fiscal year. The income tax of the electronic segment
	was comprised of income tax expense of $54,000 for the year ended March 31, 2016, as compared to income tax expense of $43,000
	in fiscal 2015.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 6PT 0.05IN 6PT 0">
<I>
	Loss from continuing operations
</I>
	&ndash; The
	Company had a net loss from continuing operations of $4,934,000 for the year ended March 31, 2016, as compared to a net loss from
	continuing operations of $2,460,000 for the year ended March 31, 2015. The increase in net loss was mainly the result of decreases
	in other and non-operating income as described above.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 6PT 0.05IN 6PT 0">
	Net loss for the plastic segment for the year ended
	March 31, 2016 totaled $2,776,000, as compared to a net loss of $505,000 for fiscal 2015. The increase in net loss in the plastic
	segment was mainly due to decreases in other and non-operating income described above.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 6PT 0.05IN 6PT 0">
	Net loss for the electronic segment for the year
	ended March 31, 2016 was $2,158,000, compared to net loss of $1,955,000 for fiscal 2015. The increase in net loss in the electronic
	segment was mainly attributable to a decrease in non-operating income as described above.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: BOLD 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 6PT 0.05IN 6PT 0">
	Year ended March 31, 2015 (Fiscal 2015) Compared
	to Year Ended March 31, 2014 (Fiscal 2014)
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 0 0.05IN 0 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
<I>
	Net Sales
</I>
	- The Company&rsquo;s
	net sales from continuing operations for the year ended March 31, 2015 were $38,076,000, a decrease of $2,856,000 or 7.0% as compared
	to $40,932,000 in the corresponding period in fiscal 2014. The decrease was related to an increase in sales revenues of $434,000
	in our plastic segment and a decrease of $3,290,000 in our electronic segment, as compared with the respective net sales from these
	segments in the corresponding period of the prior fiscal year.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 0 0.05IN 0 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 0 0.05IN 0 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	The revenue increase in the plastic
	segment was due to a slight improvement in sales orders from existing customers. The increase in net sales was related to an increase
	of $2,634,000 in orders from existing customers for motor vehicle, office equipment and local sales, offsetting a decrease of $2,200,000
	in orders from existing customers for motor vehicle and office equipment.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 0 0.05IN 0 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 0 0.05IN 0 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	The revenue decrease in the electronic
	segment was mainly due to a decrease of $4,713,000 in orders from existing customers for home entertainment products and professional
	audio instruments, offsetting an increase of $1,423,000 in orders for professional audio equipment from new customers. The decrease
	in sales orders was still mainly attributed to the still slow recovery in the American and European economies.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 0 0.05IN 0 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 0 0.05IN 0 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
<I>
	Gross Profit
</I>
	- Gross profit
	from continuing operations for the year ended March 31, 2015 was $4,224,000, representing a gross profit margin of 11.1%. This
	compared with the overall gross profit and gross profit margin from continuing operations of $3,637,000 or 8.9% for the year ended
	March 31, 2014.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 0 0.05IN 0 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 0 0.05IN 0 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	Gross profit in the plastic segment
	increased by $1,078,000 to $3,335,000 or 16.9% of net sales for the year ended March 31, 2015, as compared to $2,257,000 or 11.7%
	of net sales, for the same period in the prior fiscal year. The increase in gross margin for the plastic segment was mainly due
	to decreases, as percentage of net sales, in labor costs resulting from headcount reduction, and in depreciation expense, when
	compared with last fiscal year.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 0 0.05IN 0 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 0 0.05IN 0 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	Gross profit in the electronic segment
	decreased by $491,000 to $889,000 or 4.9% of net sales for the year ended March 31, 2015, as compared to $1,380,000 or 6.4% of
	net sales, for last fiscal year. The decrease in gross margin was mainly attributed to an increase in labor cost arising from additional
	allowances as compared with last fiscal year.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 0 0.05IN 0 0">
<I>
	&nbsp;
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 0 0.05IN 0 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
<I>
	Selling, general and administrative
	expenses
</I>
	- SG&amp;A expenses from continuing operations for the year ended March 31, 2015 were $9,123,000 or 24.0% of net sales
	from continuing operations, as compared to $10,257,000 or 25.1% of net sales from continuing operations for the year ended March
	31, 2014. Selling, general and administrative expenses from continuing operations decreased by $1,134,000 or 11.1% in fiscal 2015
	compared to last fiscal year.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 0 0.05IN 0 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<!-- FIELD: PAGE; SEQUENCE: 33; VALUE: 2 -->
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP: 6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 6PT; BORDER-BOTTOM: BLACK 4PT SOLID">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP: 0PT; TEXT-ALIGN: CENTER; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0PT; FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF">
<!-- FIELD: SEQUENCE; TYPE: ARABIC; NAME: PAGENO -->
	33
<!-- FIELD: /SEQUENCE -->
	&nbsp;
</P>
</DIV>
<A NAME="eolPage34"></A>
<DIV STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: ALWAYS; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 6PT">
<P STYLE="MARGIN: 0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
</DIV>
<!-- FIELD: /PAGE -->
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 0 0.05IN 0 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	SG&amp;A expenses in the plastic
	segment decreased by $918,000 to $5,800,000 or 29.3% of net sales for the year ended March 31, 2015, compared to $6,718,000 or
	34.7% of net sales for fiscal 2014. The decrease was primarily related to decreases of $677,000 in administrative staff cost, $83,000
	in utility cost, $75,000 in legal and professional fees, $72,000 in local government taxes and $129,000 in depreciation expense,
	offsetting an increase of $139,000 in stock compensation cost, as compared with the same period in the prior fiscal year.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 0 0.05IN 0 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 0 0.05IN 0 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	SG&amp;A expenses in the electronic
	segment decreased by $216,000 to $3,323,000 or 18.2% of net sales for the year ended March 31, 2015, compared to $3,539,000 or
	16.4% of net sales for fiscal 2014. The decrease was mainly due to decreases of $42,000 in administrative staff costs, $91,000
	in legal and professional fees, $71,000 in local government taxes, offsetting an increase of $60,000 in stock compensation cost,
	when compared to prior fiscal year.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 0 0.05IN 0 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 0 0.05IN 0 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
<I>
	Other income
</I>
	- Other income
	from continuing operations was $93,000 for the year ended March 31, 2015, as compared to other expense from continuing operations
	of $214,000 in prior fiscal year.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 0 0.05IN 0 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 0 0.05IN 0 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	On a segment basis, other income
	attributable to the plastic segment for the year ended March 31, 2015 was $9,000, as compared to other expense of $370,000 for
	prior fiscal year. The increase in other income was mainly due to gains on disposal of fixed assets of $259,000 and of $20,000
	for materials, offsetting an exchange loss of $170,000 and a provision of $98,000 for doubtful receivables, as compared to charges
	of $490,000 for impairment of property, plant and equipment, offsetting gains of $301,000 from the sale of fixed assets and of
	$58,000 from the sale of materials during fiscal 2014.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 0 0.05IN 0 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 0 0.05IN 0 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	Other income attributable to the
	electronic segment for the year ended March 31, 2015 was $84,000, as compared with other income of $156,000 for the prior fiscal
	year. This decrease in other income was mainly due to a gain of $3,000 on the disposal of fixed assets and income of $75,000 from
	the sale of materials and others during the year ended March 31, 2015, as compared to a reversal of provisions of $54,000 for doubtful
	receivables, a gain of $74,000 on disposal of fixed assets, write-off of long term accounts payables of $57,000 during last fiscal
	year.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 0 0.05IN 0 0">
<I>
	&nbsp;
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 0 0.05IN 0 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
<I>
	Operating Loss
</I>
	- Operating
	loss from continuing operations was $4,806,000 for the year ended March 31, 2015, as compared to operating loss from continuing
	operations of $6,834,000 in prior fiscal year.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 0 0.05IN 0 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 0 0.05IN 0 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	On a segment basis, the operating
	loss in the plastic segment was $2,456,000 in the year ended March 31, 2015, as compared to an operating loss of $4,831,000 in
	fiscal 2014. The decrease in operating loss in the plastic segment was mainly due to an increase in gross margin and a decrease
	in SG&amp;A expense as a percentage of net sales.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 0 0.05IN 0 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 0 0.05IN 0 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	The electronic segment reported an
	operating loss of $2,350,000 in the year ended March 31, 2015, compared to an operating loss of $2,003,000 in fiscal 2014.&nbsp;&nbsp;The
	increase in operating loss was largely due to a decrease in turnover as described above.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 0 0.05IN 0 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 0 0.05IN 0 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
<I>
	Non-operating income
</I>
	&ndash;
	Non-operating income from continuing operations for the year ended March 31, 2015 was $2,553,000, as compared to non-operating
	income from continuing operations of $379,000 in last fiscal year.&nbsp;&nbsp;This was primarily due to an increase of $1,819,000
	in unrealized gain on the revaluation of marketable securities as compared to fiscal 2014.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 0 0.05IN 0 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 0 0.05IN 0 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
<I>
	Income Taxes
</I>
	&ndash; Income
	tax from continuing operations for the year ended March 31, 2015 represented a current income tax expense of $92,000 and a deferred
	tax provision of $115,000, as compared to a current income tax expense of $347,000 and a deferred tax provision of $277,000 in
	last fiscal year.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 0 0.05IN 0 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 0 0.05IN 0 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	On a segment basis, there was current
	income tax expense of $49,000 and a deferred tax provision of $115,000 in the plastic segment for the year ended March 31, 2015,
	as compared to current income tax expense of $54,000 and a deferred tax provision of $84,000 during the last fiscal year. The current
	income tax of the electronic segment was comprised of current income tax expense of $43,000 for the year ended March 31, 2015,
	as compared to current income tax expense of $293,000 and a deferred tax provision of $193,000 in fiscal 2014.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 0 0.05IN 0 0">
<I>
	&nbsp;
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 0 0.05IN 0 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
<I>
	Loss from continuing operations
</I>
	&ndash; The Company had a net loss from continuing operations of $2,460,000 for the year ended March 31, 2015, as compared to a
	net loss from continuing operations of $7,079,000 for the year
</P>
<!-- FIELD: PAGE; SEQUENCE: 34; VALUE: 2 -->
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP: 6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 6PT; BORDER-BOTTOM: BLACK 4PT SOLID">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP: 0PT; TEXT-ALIGN: CENTER; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0PT; FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF">
<!-- FIELD: SEQUENCE; TYPE: ARABIC; NAME: PAGENO -->
	34
<!-- FIELD: /SEQUENCE -->
	&nbsp;
</P>
</DIV>
<A NAME="eolPage35"></A>
<DIV STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: ALWAYS; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 6PT">
<P STYLE="MARGIN: 0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
</DIV>
<!-- FIELD: /PAGE -->
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 0 0.05IN 0 0">
	ended March 31, 2014.&nbsp;&nbsp; The decrease in net
	loss was mainly the result of increases in gross margin and non-operating income as described above.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 0 0.05IN 0 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 0 0.05IN 0 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	Net loss for the plastic segment
	for the year ended March 31, 2015 totaled $505,000, as compared to a net loss of $4,655,000 for fiscal 2014.&nbsp;&nbsp;The decrease
	in net loss in the plastic segment was mainly the result of increases in gross margin and non-operating income as well as a decrease
	in SG&amp;A expense as a percentage of net sales as described above.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 0 0.05IN 0 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 0 0.05IN 0 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	Net loss for the electronic segment
	for the year ended March 31, 2015 was $1,955,000, compared to net loss of $2,424,000 for fiscal 2014.&nbsp;&nbsp;The decrease in
	net loss of the electronic segment was mainly attributable to a decrease in SG&amp;A and an increase in non-operating income as
	described above.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 0 0.05IN 0 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 0 0.05IN 0 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
<I>
	Loss from discontinued operations
</I>
	- During the fourth quarter of fiscal 2015, the Company closed down its metallic part business unit and sold all of its assets.
	The operating results of the metallic part business unit are reported as discontinued operations for all periods presented. We
	had historically reported the results of the metallic part business unit as a separate segment. The continuing cash flows subsequent
	to its closure were not significant.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 6PT 0.05IN 6PT 0">
	The results of the discontinued operations of metallic
	part for the fiscal years ended March 31, 2014, 2015 and 2016 were as follows:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 6PT 0.05IN 6PT 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>

<EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<A NAME="FIS_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE_9"></A>
<P STYLE="FONT: BOLD 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 6PT 0.05IN 6PT 0">
	Seasonality
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 6PT 0.05IN 6PT 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	The following table sets forth
	certain unaudited quarterly financial information sequentially for the four quarters in each of the three years in the period ended
	March 31, 2016 (in thousands):
</P>

<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 0 0.05IN 0 0">
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 0">
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: 9PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 0">
	(1)&#9;The sum of the unaudited quarterly financial data may not
	be equal to the respective figures as stated in the audited financial statements because of the posting of reclassifications.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 6PT 0.05IN 6PT 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	The first calendar quarter (the
	fourth fiscal quarter ending March 31 of our fiscal year) is typically the Company&rsquo;s slowest sales period because, as is
	customary in China, the Company&rsquo;s manufacturing facilities in
</P>
<!-- FIELD: PAGE; SEQUENCE: 35; VALUE: 2 -->
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP: 6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 6PT; BORDER-BOTTOM: BLACK 4PT SOLID">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP: 0PT; TEXT-ALIGN: CENTER; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0PT; FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF">
<!-- FIELD: SEQUENCE; TYPE: ARABIC; NAME: PAGENO -->
	35
<!-- FIELD: /SEQUENCE -->
	&nbsp;
</P>
</DIV>
<A NAME="eolPage36"></A>
<DIV STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: ALWAYS; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 6PT">
<P STYLE="MARGIN: 0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
</DIV>
<!-- FIELD: /PAGE -->
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 6PT 0.05IN 6PT 0">
	China are closed for two weeks for the Chinese New
	Year holidays. Through March 31, 2016, the Company has not experienced any other significant seasonal fluctuations.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: BOLD 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 6PT 0.05IN 6PT 0">
	Impact of Inflation
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 6PT 0.05IN 6PT 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	Historically, the Company focused
	upon increasing transaction volume in order to compensate for inflation in China, where virtually all of the Company&rsquo;s assets
	and employees are located and inflation in China had little impact on Deswell. However, inflation in China has recently affected
	the Company significantly.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 6PT 0.05IN 6PT 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	The inflation rate in China was
	recorded at 2.3% in April of 2016. However, the Company&rsquo;s actual cost of operations has significantly exceeded the overall
	inflation rate in China. The rapid growth of China&rsquo;s economy in general has in the past few years increased the Company&rsquo;s
	operating costs, including energy prices and labor costs. These increased costs have adversely affected the Company&rsquo;s cost
	of operations, caused the Company to increase its prices, and resulted in the loss of some customers.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 6PT 0.05IN 6PT 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	There is no fixed minimum wage
	which is applicable to all of China; local governments in China adopt different amounts based on the situation in their area. China&rsquo;s
	Guangdong Province, where our manufacturing facilities are located, raised minimum wages by approximately 20% in May 2011 and another
	19.1% in March 2013. Effective May 1, 2015, minimum wage levels across Guangdong Province, including Dongguan, where our manufacturing
	facilities are located, were increased by an average of 15.3%.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 6PT 0.05IN 6PT 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	Increases in wages also result
	in increases in our and other employer&rsquo;s contributions for various mandatory social welfare benefits for Chinese employees
	that are based on percentages of their salaries. Continuing material increases in our cost of labor will continue to increase the
	Company&rsquo;s operating costs and will adversely affect Deswell&rsquo;s financial results unless it passes on such increases
	to customers by increasing the prices of products and services. The effect of increases in the prices of products and services
	would make the Company&rsquo;s products more expensive in global markets, such as the United States and the European Union. This
	could result in the loss of customers, who may seek, and be able to obtain, products and services comparable to those Deswell offers
	in lower-cost regions of the world. If the Company does not increase prices to pass on the effect of increases in labor costs,
	Deswell&rsquo;s margins and profitability would suffer.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 6PT 0.05IN 6PT 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	Because most of the Company&rsquo;s
	labor costs are incurred in China and therefore paid in RMB, the adverse effect on Deswell&rsquo;s business and financial results
	from increasing labor costs has in previous years been exacerbated by the appreciation in the exchange rate to the U.S. dollar,
	as is discussed in &ldquo;Exchange Rates&rdquo; immediately below. However, in fiscal 2016, the RMB depreciated relative to the
	U.S. dollar, with the exchange rate mitigating rather than exacerbating the increasing labor costs experienced by the Company.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: BOLD 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 6PT 0.05IN 6PT 0">
	Exchange Rates
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 6PT 0.05IN 6PT 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	The Company&rsquo;s sales are
	mainly in United States dollars and Hong Kong dollars and its expenses are mainly in United States dollars, Hong Kong dollars and
	Chinese RMB.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 6PT 0.05IN 6PT 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	The Hong Kong dollar has been
	pegged to the U.S. dollar at approximately 7.80 and relatively stable. The Hong Kong government may not continue to maintain the
	present currency exchange mechanism, which fixes the Hong Kong dollar at approximately 7.80 to each United States dollar and has
	not in the past presented a material currency exchange risk. Although announcements by Hong Kong&rsquo;s central bank indicate
	its intention to maintain the currency peg between the Hong Kong dollar and the U.S. dollar, if Hong Kong does change and follows
	China to a floating currency system or otherwise changes the exchange rate system of Hong Kong dollars to U.S. dollars, our margins
	and financial results could be adversely affected.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 6PT 0.05IN 6PT 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	Between 1994 and July 2005, the
	market and official RMB rates were unified and the value of the RMB was essentially pegged to the U.S. dollar and was relatively
	stable. On July 21, 2005, the People&rsquo;s Bank of China adjusted the exchange rate of RMB to the U.S. dollar by linking the
	RMB to a basket of currencies and simultaneously setting the exchange rate of RMB to U.S. dollars, from 1:8.27, to a narrow band
	of around 1:8.11. The following chart illustrates the fluctuations since the July 31, 2005 adjustment of the RMB to the U.S. dollar
	by showing the exchange ratio at the end of each of Deswell&rsquo;s fiscal years from March 31, 2006 to March 31, 2016.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 0 0.05IN 0 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<!-- FIELD: PAGE; SEQUENCE: 36; VALUE: 2 -->
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP: 6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 6PT; BORDER-BOTTOM: BLACK 4PT SOLID">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP: 0PT; TEXT-ALIGN: CENTER; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0PT; FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF">

<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 6PT 0.05IN 6PT 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	We did not hedge our currency
	risk during the years ended March 31, 2014, 2015 and 2016 and at March 31, 2016, we had no open forward currency contracts. We
	continually review our hedging strategy and there can be no assurance that hedging techniques we may implement will be successful
	or will not result in charges to our results of operations.
</P>
<EFX_LIQUIDITY_CAPITAL>
<A NAME="FIS_LIQUIDITY_CAPITAL"></A>
<P STYLE="FONT: BOLD 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 6PT 0.05IN 6PT 0">
	Liquidity and Capital Resources
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 6PT 0.05IN 6PT 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	For the year ended March 31,
	2016, net cash provided by operations totaled $563,000, including a net loss of $4,934,000, and depreciation and amortization expenses
	of $2,373,000. Accounts receivable decreased by $95,000 as compared to balances at March 31, 2015, primarily as a result of shorter
	collection days generated during the fiscal year. Inventories decreased by $2,966,000 over levels at March 31, 2015, primarily
	because of relatively lower cost of purchase and effective usage for raw materials during the fiscal year. Accounts payable decreased
	by $1,120,000 over levels at March 31, 2015, primarily because of the decrease in materials purchases. For the year ended March
	31, 2015, net cash used in operations totaled $2,370,000, including a net loss of $2,808,000 and depreciation and amortization
	expenses of $2,824,000.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 6PT 0.05IN 6PT 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	Net cash used in investing activities
	amounted to $1,206,000 for the year ended March 31, 2016, while net cash used in investing activities in fiscal 2015 amounted to
	$3,612,000. Capital expenditures during these periods totaled $ 591,000 and $890,000, respectively. Our capital expenditures were
	primarily related to the acquisition of property, plant and equipment, and leasehold improvements for our two manufacturing plants
	in Dongguan, China. In fiscal 2016, there was a decrease in fixed deposits over three months for $4,635,000 and an increase in
	fixed deposits over twelve months for $2,965,000.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 6PT 0.05IN 6PT 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	In fiscal 2016, we acquired marketable
	securities for $10,349,000 and received cash proceeds from sale of the marketable securities for $6,798,000.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 6PT 0.05IN 6PT 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	Net cash used in financing activities
	for the years ended March 31, 2016 and 2015 were $1,686,000 and $2,971,000, respectively. Net cash we used in financing activities
	during the year ended March 31, 2016 and 2015 were solely to fund dividend payments to shareholders.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 6PT 0.05IN 6PT 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	As a consequence of the fixed
	exchange rate between the Hong Kong dollar and the U.S. dollar, interest rates on Hong Kong dollar borrowings are similar to U.S.
	interest rates. The Hong Kong Prime Rate at March 31, 2016 remained at 5.0%, the same rate it was at March 31, 2015 and at March
	31, 2014.
</P>
<!-- FIELD: PAGE; SEQUENCE: 37; VALUE: 2 -->
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP: 6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 6PT; BORDER-BOTTOM: BLACK 4PT SOLID">

</DIV>
<!-- FIELD: /PAGE -->
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 6PT 0.05IN 6PT 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	At March 31, 2016, the Company
	had cash and cash equivalents of $11,996,000. At that date, Deswell had no committed credit facilities and no restricted cash.
	Deswell expects that working capital requirements and capital additions will continue to be funded through cash on hand and internally
	generated funds. However, Deswell may choose to seek to obtain additional debt or equity financing if it believes it to be appropriate
	and available on reasonable terms. The Company&rsquo;s working capital requirements are expected to increase in line with the growth
	in the Company&rsquo;s business.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 6PT 0.05IN 6PT 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	At March 31, 2016, the Company
	had capital commitments totaling approximately $18,000 mainly to purchase plant and machinery, and leasehold improvements, which
	are expected to be disbursed during the year ending March 31, 2017.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 6PT 0.05IN 6PT 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	A summary of our contractual
	obligations and commercial commitments as of March 31, 2016 is as follows:
</P>

<P STYLE="FONT: BOLD 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 6PT 0.05IN 6PT 0">
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: BOLD 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 6PT 0.05IN 6PT 0">
	Off Balance Sheet Arrangements
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 6PT 0.05IN 6PT 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	We do not use off-balance sheet
	financing arrangements, such as securitization of receivables or obtaining access to assets through special purpose entities.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: BOLD 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 6PT 0.05IN 6PT 0">
	Critical Accounting Policies and Estimates
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 6PT 0.05IN 6PT 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	The preparation of our consolidated
	financial statements and related disclosures in conformity with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States requires
	management to make estimates and judgments that affect our reported amounts of assets and liabilities, revenues and expenses, and
	related disclosures of contingent assets and liabilities. On an on-going basis, we evaluate our estimates and assumptions based
	upon historical experience and various other factors and circumstances. Management believes that our estimates and assumptions
	are reasonable under the circumstances; however, actual results may vary from these estimates and assumptions under different future
	circumstances. For more information on our significant accounting policies, refer to Note 2 of Notes to Consolidated Financial
	Statements included in Part III,
<FONT STYLE="FONT-VARIANT: SMALL-CAPS">
	Item
</FONT>
	18, in this Report.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 6PT 0.05IN 6PT 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	We have identified the following
	most critical accounting policies, that involved a high degree of judgments and estimates, used in the preparation of our consolidated
	financial statements:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: ITALIC 10PT TIMES NEW; MARGIN: 6PT 0">
	Inventories
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 6PT 0.05IN 6PT 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	Our inventories are stated at
	the lower of cost or market. Cost is determined on the weighted average basis. Work-in-progress and finished goods inventories
	consist of raw materials, direct labor and overhead associated with the manufacturing process. The Company periodically performs
	an analysis of inventory to determine obsolete or slow-moving inventory and determine if its cost exceeds the estimated market
	value. Write down of potentially obsolete or slow-moving inventory are recorded based on management&rsquo;s analysis of inventory
	levels.
</P>
<!-- FIELD: PAGE; SEQUENCE: 38; VALUE: 2 -->
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP: 6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 6PT; BORDER-BOTTOM: BLACK 4PT SOLID">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP: 0PT; TEXT-ALIGN: CENTER; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0PT; FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF">
<!-- FIELD: SEQUENCE; TYPE: ARABIC; NAME: PAGENO -->
	38
<!-- FIELD: /SEQUENCE -->
	&nbsp;
</P>
</DIV>
<A NAME="eolPage39"></A>
<DIV STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: ALWAYS; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 6PT">
<P STYLE="MARGIN: 0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
</DIV>
<!-- FIELD: /PAGE -->
<P STYLE="FONT: ITALIC 10PT TIMES NEW; MARGIN: 6PT 0">
	Impairment of long-lived assets
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 6PT 0.05IN 6PT 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	Our long-lived assets are included
	in impairment evaluations when events and circumstances exist that indicate the carrying value of these assets may not be recoverable.
	In accordance with ASC No. 360, &ldquo;Property, Plant and Equipment,&rdquo; the Company assesses the recoverability of the carrying
	value of long-lived assets by first grouping its long-lived assets with other assets and liabilities at the lowest level for which
	identifiable cash flows largely independent of the cash flows of other assets and liabilities (the asset group) and, secondly,
	estimating the undiscounted future cash flows that are directly associated with and expected to arise from the use of and eventual
	disposition of such asset group. The Company estimates the undiscounted cash flows over the remaining useful life of the primary
	asset within the asset group. If the carrying value of the asset group exceeds the estimated undiscounted cash flows, the Company
	records an impairment charge to the extent the carrying value of the long-lived asset exceeds its fair value. The Company determines
	fair value through quoted market prices in active markets or, if quotations of market prices are unavailable, through the performance
	of internal analysis using a discounted cash flow methodology. The undiscounted and discounted cash flow analyses based on a number
	of estimates and assumptions, including the expected period over which the asset will be utilized, projected future operating results
	of the asset group, discount rate and long-term growth rate.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 6PT 0.05IN 6PT 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	In evaluation of undiscounted
	projected cash-flows associated with those assets, the Company assessed that certain of its long-lived assets at the reporting
	date to be less than the fair value and the sum of undiscounted cash flows. Accordingly, the Company impaired that the carrying
	values of long-lived assets of, $490,000, $0, and $0 for the years ended March 31, 2014, 2015 and 2016, respectively. In fiscal
	2016, there were no impairment charges on the carrying values of long-lived assets based on management&rsquo;s assessment and review.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: ITALIC 10PT TIMES NEW; MARGIN: 6PT 0">
	Allowance for doubtful accounts
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 6PT 0.05IN 6PT 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	The Company regularly monitors
	and assesses the risk of not collecting amounts owed to the Company by customers. This evaluation is based upon a variety of factors
	including: ongoing credit evaluations of its customers&rsquo; financial condition, an analysis of amounts current and past due
	along with relevant history and facts particular to the customer. Based upon the results of this analysis, the Company records
	an allowance for uncollectible accounts for this risk. This analysis requires the Company to make significant estimates, and changes
	in facts and circumstances could result in material changes in the allowance for doubtful accounts. Unanticipated changes in the
	liquidity or financial position of the Company&rsquo;s customers may require additional provisions for doubtful accounts.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: ITALIC 10PT TIMES NEW; MARGIN: 6PT 0">
	Goodwill
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 6PT 0.05IN 6PT 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	The excess purchase price over
	the fair value of net assets acquired is recorded on the balance sheet as goodwill. The Company adopted Accounting Standards Codification
	(&ldquo;ASC&rdquo;) No. 350, &ldquo;Intangibles &ndash; Goodwill and Other,&rdquo; which requires the carrying value of goodwill
	to be evaluated for impairment on an annual basis or more frequently if impairment indicators arise. The Company regularly conducted
	annual impairment evaluation. The impairment test requires the Company to estimate the fair value of our reporting units. If the
	carrying value of a reporting unit exceeds its fair value, the goodwill of that reporting unit is potentially impaired and the
	Company proceeds to step two of the impairment analysis. In the second step, the implied fair value of the reporting unit&rsquo;s
	goodwill is determined by allocating the reporting unit&rsquo;s fair value to all of its assets and liabilities other than goodwill
	(including any unrecognized intangible assets) in a manner similar to a purchase price allocation. The resulting implied fair value
	of the goodwill that results from the application of the second step is then compared to the carrying amount of the goodwill and
	an impairment charge is recorded for the difference. The assumptions used in the estimate of fair value are generally consistent
	with the past performance of each reporting unit and are consistent with the projections and assumptions that are used in current
	operating plans. Such assumptions are subject to change as a result of changing economic and competitive conditions.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 6PT 0.05IN 6PT 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	Based on the result of the first
	step of the goodwill impairment analysis, the Company determined that the fair value of electronic division was less than its carrying
	value as of March 31, 2014 and, as such, the Company applied the second step of the goodwill impairment test to this segment. Based
	on the result of the second step of the goodwill impairment test, the Company recorded a $392,000 impairment charge to reduce the
	carrying value of goodwill in electronic division for the year ended March 31, 2014. The entire goodwill was fully impaired and,
	during fiscal years 2015 and 2016, there were no impairment charges on goodwill after management&rsquo;s assessment and review.
</P>
<!-- FIELD: PAGE; SEQUENCE: 39; VALUE: 2 -->

</EFX_OPERATING_AND_FINANCIAL_REVIEW>

</EFX_NAME_AND_TITLE>
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 6PT 0.05IN 6PT 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 6PT 0.05IN 6PT 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
<U>
	Richard Pui Hon Lau
</U>
	. Mr.
	Lau served as Chief Executive Officer and Chairman of the Board of Directors of the Company and its predecessors since their inception
	in 1987 until February 2007, at which time he retired as Chief Executive Officer. Mr. Lau remains as Chairman of the Board.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 6PT 0.05IN 6PT 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
<U>
	Edward So Kin Chung
</U>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-VARIANT: SMALL-CAPS">
	.
</FONT>
	Mr. So has been in the electronic manufacturing industry internationally and in China for more than 15 years and has been with
	Deswell for 8 years. He was recently appointed the Managing Director of the electronics division. Previously, Mr. So spent five
	years at Peavey Electronics in increasing roles of responsibility and prior to that was employed at HSBC. Mr. So holds a Bachelor&rsquo;s
	degree in Electrical and Electronic Engineering from the University of Hong Kong, and Master&rsquo;s in Business Administration
	from Royal Holloway, University of London.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 6PT 0.05IN 6PT 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
<U>
	Chin Pang Li
</U>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-VARIANT: SMALL-CAPS">
	.
</FONT>
	Mr. Li has served the Company as a Member of the Board of Directors and in various executive capacities with the Company and its
	predecessors since their inception in 1987. He became Secretary of the Company in February 1995 and Chief Financial Officer in
	May 1995, a position which he held until March 31, 2006. As Executive Director
<STRIKE>
</STRIKE>
	of Manufacturing and Administration
	for Plastic Operations, Mr. Li is in charge of the
<STRIKE>
</STRIKE>
	manufacturing and administrative operations for the Company&rsquo;s
	plastic products. Mr. Li received his Bachelor of Science degree from Chun Yan Institute College, Taiwan in 1967.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 6PT 0.05IN 6PT 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
<U>
	Hung-Hum Leung
</U>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-VARIANT: SMALL-CAPS">
	.
</FONT>
	Mr. Leung has been a non-executive director of the Company and member of the Audit Committee since December 1999. Mr. Leung has
	over 25 years of experience in the manufacture of electronic products. Mr. Leung was the founder of Sharp Brave Holdings Ltd. (since
	2007 known as China Properties Investment Holdings Limited), a Hong Kong public company listed on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange,
	and from 1991 to 1995 served as the Chairman of Sharp Brave Holdings Ltd. Since 1995, Mr. Leung has been an independent consultant
	to the electronics industry. He received his Bachelor of Science degree in Physics from the National Taiwan University in 1971.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 6PT 0.05IN 6PT 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
<U>
	Allen Yau-Nam Cham
</U>
	. Mr.
	Cham has been a non-executive director of the Company and member of the Audit Committee since August 2003.&nbsp;He has over 20
	years of experience in the securities industry. He obtained his Bachelor of Science degree from St. Mary&rsquo;s University, Halifax,
	Canada, Bachelor of Engineering (Electrical) degree from Nova Scotia Technical College, Halifax, Canada and Master of Business
	Administration degree from University of British Columbia, Canada.
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY: TAHOMA, HELVETICA, SANS-SERIF">
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 6PT 0.05IN 6PT 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
<U>
	Wing-Ki Hui
</U>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY: TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; FONT-VARIANT: SMALL-CAPS">
<B>
	.
</B>
</FONT>
	Mr. Hui has been a non-executive director of the Company and member of the Audit Committee since October 2004. Since
	1995 he has been the Operation Director of the Electronic Products Division of Tomorrow International Holdings Limited, a company
	listed on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange engaged in manufacturing of consumer electronics and printed circuit boards. Prior to serving
	in this capacity, Mr. Hui was Executive Director of Sharp Brave International Holdings Limited from 1991 to 1995 and Director of
	Sharp Brave Electronics Co., Ltd. from 1984 to 1995. Mr. Hui possesses over 20 years of experience in the electronic manufacturing
	industry, and is a graduate of South East Electronic College in Hong Kong.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 6PT 0.05IN 6PT 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
<U>
	Herman Wong Chi Wah
</U>
	. Mr.
	Wong joined the Company as Chief Financial Officer effective on April 1, 2011. During the 10 years immediately before joining Deswell,
	Mr. Wong worked for Deloitte Touche Tohmatsu, an international public accounting and auditing firm, where he most recently served
	as senior manager. During his tenure at Deloitte Touch Tohmatsu, he worked in an auditing capacity with a variety of Hong Kong
	listed
</P>

<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP: 6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 6PT; BORDER-BOTTOM: BLACK 4PT SOLID">

<!-- FIELD: /PAGE -->
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 6PT 0.05IN 6PT 0">
	companies and multinational corporations as well
	as working on several initial public offerings for Hong Kong listed companies. Mr. Wong received his Bachelor of Business Administration
	in Accounting from Hong Kong Polytechnic University.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 6PT 0.05IN 6PT 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	No family relationship exists
	among any of the named directors, executive officers or key employees. No arrangement or understanding exists between any director
	or officer and any other persons pursuant to which any director or executive officer was elected as a director or executive officer
	of the Company.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 0 0.05IN 0 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	There are no arrangements or understandings
	with major shareholders, customers, suppliers or others, pursuant to which any member of the board of directors or senior management
	was selected as a director or member of senior management.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: BOLD 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 6PT 0.05IN 6PT 0">
	Compensation of Directors and Executive Officers
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: ITALIC 10PT TIMES NEW; MARGIN: 6PT 0">
	Executive Officers
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 6PT 0.05IN 6PT 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	The amount of compensation (cash
	benefits) paid by the Company and its subsidiaries was approximately $1,402,000 during the year ended March 31, 2016 to all directors
	and to executive officers as a group for services in all service capacities. These amounts exclude amounts paid by the Company
	or its subsidiaries as dividends to directors and executive officers in their capacity as shareholders of the Company for the year
	ended March 31, 2016.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 6PT 0.05IN 6PT 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	During the year ended March 31,
	2016, no options to purchase shares of common stock were granted to the Company&rsquo;s directors and officers.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 6PT 0.05IN 6PT 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	See the discussion under &ldquo;We
	depend on our executive officers, senior managers and skilled personnel.&rdquo; in
<FONT STYLE="FONT-VARIANT: SMALL-CAPS">
	Item
</FONT>
	3 &ldquo;Key Information &ndash; Risk Factors&rdquo; on page 16 of this Report.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: ITALIC 10PT TIMES NEW; MARGIN: 6PT 0">
	Directors
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 6PT 0.05IN 6PT 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	Our policy is to pay directors
	who are not employees of the Company or any of its subsidiaries $2,000 per month for services as a director, and to reimburse directors
	for all reasonable expenses incurred in connection with their services as a director and member of Board committees.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 6PT 0.05IN 6PT 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	The Board has determined that
	Messrs. Hung-Hum Leung, Allen Yau-Nam Cham and Wing-Ki Hui are each &ldquo;independent&rdquo; within the meaning of Rule 5605(a)
	(2) of the NASDAQ Marketplace Rules.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: BOLD 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 6PT 0.05IN 6PT 0">
	Board Practices
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 6PT 0.05IN 6PT 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	The directors of the Company
	are elected at its annual meeting of shareholders and serve until their successors take office or until their death, resignation
	or removal. The executive officers serve at the pleasure of the Board of Directors of the Company
<B>
	.
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: BOLD 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 6PT 0.05IN 6PT 0">
	Audit Committee
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 6PT 0.05IN 6PT 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	The Audit Committee meets from
	time to time to review the financial statements and matters relating to the audit and has full access to management and the Company&rsquo;s
	auditors in this regard. The Audit Committee recommends the engagement or discharge of the Company&rsquo;s independent accountants,
	consults on the adequacy of the Company&rsquo;s internal controls and accounting procedures, and reviews and approves financial
	statements and reports. Deswell&rsquo;s audit committee consists of Messrs. Hung-Hum Leung, Allen Yau-Nam Cham and Wing-Ki Hui,
	each of whom is an independent director within the meaning of that term under Rule 5605(a)(2) of the NASDAQ Marketplace Rules.
	Mr. Allen Yau-Nam Cham currently acts as the Chairman of the Audit Committee.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: BOLD 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 6PT 0.05IN 6PT 0">
	Other Committees; NASDAQ Compliance
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 6PT 0.05IN 6PT 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	Various corporate governance
	practices required of U.S. domestic public companies with securities listed on The NASDAQ Stock Market, are not required of foreign
	private issuers such as Deswell if such issuers follow their home country practice. Of the corporate governance practices required
	under NASDAQ&rsquo;s Marketplace Rules of U.S. domestic public companies, Deswell follows home country practices and does not have
	a compensation committee or a nominating committee consisting of independent directors; does not have nominees to its board selected
	or recommended by a majority of its independent directors; does not have the compensation of its Chief Executive Officer and other
	executive officers determined or recommended to the board by a majority of its independent directors; and Deswell&rsquo;s independent
	directors do not meet in executive session. See &ldquo;Our exemptions from certain of the reporting requirements under the Exchange
	Act limits the protections and information afforded to investors&rdquo; on page 19 in the Risk Factors section of this Report for
	a further discussion of how our SEC reporting and corporate governance practices differ from those applicable to U.S. domestic
	issuers and U.S.
</P>
<!-- FIELD: PAGE; SEQUENCE: 41; VALUE: 2 -->
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP: 6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 6PT; BORDER-BOTTOM: BLACK 4PT SOLID">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP: 0PT; TEXT-ALIGN: CENTER; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0PT; FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF">

<A NAME="eolPage42"></A>
<DIV STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: ALWAYS; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 6PT">
<P STYLE="MARGIN: 0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
</DIV>
<!-- FIELD: /PAGE -->
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 6PT 0.05IN 6PT 0">
	NASDAQ-listed companies. The reason that Deswell
	does not have a compensation committee or a nominating committee consisting of independent directors is that, as a foreign private
	issuer, the Company is permitted under NASDAQ&rsquo;s Marketplace Rules to follow its home country practice, which does not require
	such committees, and nevertheless maintain the listing of its common shares on the NASDAQ Global Market.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: BOLD 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 6PT 0.05IN 6PT 0">
	Employees
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 6PT 0.05IN 6PT 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	At March 31, 2016, the Company
	employed 1,220 persons on a full-time basis, of which ten were located in Macao and 1,210 were located in or travel to and from
	China. Of the Company&rsquo;s employees in China, at March 31, 2016:
</P>
<TABLE CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%" STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 6PT">

<TD STYLE="WIDTH: 0.75IN">
</TD>
<TD STYLE="WIDTH: 0.25IN">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY: SYMBOL">
	&#183;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD STYLE="PADDING-RIGHT: 0.05IN">
	850 were engaged in plastic injection molding manufacturing, and
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<TABLE CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%" STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 6PT">
<TR STYLE="VERTICAL-ALIGN: TOP">
<TD STYLE="WIDTH: 0.75IN">
</TD>
<TD STYLE="WIDTH: 0.25IN">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY: SYMBOL">
	&#183;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD STYLE="PADDING-RIGHT: 0.05IN">
	350 were engaged in contract electronic manufacturing, metal molds and parts manufacturing.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 6PT 0.05IN 6PT 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	In response to prevailing business
	conditions, we reduced our workforce by 360, 10, and 68 during the years ended March 31, 2014, 2015 and 2016, respectively.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 6PT 0.05IN 6PT 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	The Company has not experienced
	significant labor stoppages. Management believes that relations with the Company&rsquo;s employees are satisfactory.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: BOLD 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 6PT 0.05IN 6PT 0">
	Share and Option Ownership of Directors and
	Senior Management
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 6PT 0.05IN 6PT 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	For information concerning the
	beneficial ownership of the Company&rsquo;s common shares, including options, by directors and senior management and major shareholders,
	see
<FONT STYLE="FONT-VARIANT: SMALL-CAPS">
	Item
</FONT>
	7 of this Report.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: BOLD 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 6PT 0.05IN 6PT 0">
	Employee Stock Option Plans
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 6PT 0.05IN 6PT 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	In 1995, the Company adopted
	its 1995 Stock Option Plan permitting the Company to grant options to purchase up to 1,012,500 common shares to employees, officers,
	directors and consultants of the Company. On September 29, 1997, the Company&rsquo;s Board of Directors and shareholders approved
	an increase of 549,000 shares in the number of shares that can be optioned and sold under the Option Plan bringing to a total of
	1,561,500 shares the number of common shares that can be optioned and sold under the 1995 Stock Option Plan. No shares remain available
	for grant under the Company&rsquo;s 1995 Stock Option Plan.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 6PT 0.05IN 6PT 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	On August 15, 2001 the Board
	approved the adoption of the 2001 Stock Option Plan permitting the Company to grant options to purchase up to an additional 1,125,000
	common shares to employees, officers, directors and consultants of the Company. On January 7, 2002 shareholders approved the 2001
	plan.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 6PT 0.05IN 6PT 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	On August 20, 2003, the Board
	approved the adoption of the 2003 Stock Option Plan permitting the Company to grant options to purchase up to an additional 900,000
	common shares to employees, officers, directors, consultants and advisors of the Company. On September 30, 2003 shareholders approved
	the 2003 plan. On August 1, 2005, the Company&rsquo;s Board of Directors, subject to shareholder approval, approved amendments
	to the 2003 Stock Option to increase by 500,000 shares in the number of shares that can be optioned and sold under the 2003 Stock
	Option Plan, bringing to a total of 1,400,000 shares the number of common shares that can be optioned and sold under the 2003 Stock
	Option Plan. The Company&rsquo;s shareholders approved this amendment at the Company&rsquo;s Annual Shareholders&rsquo; Meeting
	held on September 19, 2005.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 6PT 0.05IN 6PT 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	On August 17, 2007, the Company&rsquo;s
	Board of Directors, subject to shareholder approval, approved amendments to the 2003 Stock Option to increase by 400,000 shares
	in the number of shares that can be optioned and sold under the 2003 Stock Option Plan, bringing to a total of 1,800,000 shares
	the number of common shares that can be optioned and sold under the 2003 Stock Option Plan. The Company&rsquo;s shareholders approved
	this amendment at the Company&rsquo;s Annual Shareholders&rsquo; Meeting held on October 9, 2007.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 6PT 0.05IN 6PT 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	On August 13, 2010, the Company&rsquo;s
	Board of Directors, subject to shareholder approval, approved amendments to the 2003 Stock Option Plan to increase by 800,000 shares
	in the number of shares that can be optioned and sold under the 2003 Stock Option Plan, bringing to a total of 2,600,000 shares
	the number of common shares that can be optioned and sold under the 2003 Stock Option Plan. The Company&rsquo;s shareholders approved
	this amendment at the Company&rsquo;s Annual shareholders&rsquo; Meeting held on September 16, 2010.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 6PT 0.05IN 6PT 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	On August 7, 2013, the Company&rsquo;s
	Board of Directors, subject to shareholder approval, approved amendments to the 2003 Stock Option Plan to increase by 900,000 shares
	the number of shares that can be optioned and sold under the 2003 Stock Option Plan, bringing to a total of 3,500,000 shares the
	number of common shares that can be optioned and sold under the 2003 Stock Option Plan. The Company&rsquo;s shareholders approved
	this amendment at the Company&rsquo;s Annual shareholders&rsquo; Meeting held on September 11, 2013.
</P>
<!-- FIELD: PAGE; SEQUENCE: 42; VALUE: 2 -->
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP: 6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 6PT; BORDER-BOTTOM: BLACK 4PT SOLID">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP: 0PT; TEXT-ALIGN: CENTER; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0PT; FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF">

<A NAME="eolPage43"></A>
<DIV STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: ALWAYS; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 6PT">
<P STYLE="MARGIN: 0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
</DIV>
<!-- FIELD: /PAGE -->
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 6PT 0.05IN 6PT 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	The Company&rsquo;s option plans
	are administered by the Board of Directors, which determines the terms of options granted, including the exercise price, the number
	of shares subject to the option and the option&rsquo;s exercisability. The exercise price of all options granted under the option
	plans must be at least equal to the fair market value of such shares on the date of grant. The maximum term of options granted
	under the option plans is 10 years.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 6PT 0.05IN 6PT 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	Through June 30, 2016, options
	to purchase an aggregate of 5,669,000 shares had been granted under all of Deswell&rsquo;s option plans. At June 30, 2016, there
	were options to purchase an aggregate of 532,000 common shares outstanding, and 1,236,000 shares were available for future grant
	under Deswell&rsquo;s option plans.
</P>

	Based on 16,056,239 shares outstanding on June 30, 2016. However, in accordance with Rule 13d-3(d)(1)
	under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, shares not outstanding but which are the subject of currently exercisable options have
	been considered outstanding for the purpose of computing the percentage of outstanding shares owned by the listed person holding
	such options, but are not considered outstanding for the purpose of computing the percentage of shares owned by any of the other
	listed persons.
</TD>

	(1)
</TD>
<TD STYLE="PADDING-RIGHT: 0.05IN">
	Based on 16,056,239 outstanding at June 30, 2014, 16,056,239 outstanding at June 30, 2015, and
	16,056,239 outstanding at June 30, 2016. In accordance with Rule 13d-3(d) (1) under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, common
	shares not outstanding at the specified date but which were the subject of options exercisable within 60 days of the specified
	date are considered outstanding for the purpose of computing the percentage of outstanding common shares owned by the listed person
	holding such options, but are not considered outstanding for the purpose of computing the percentage of common shares owned by
	any of the other listed persons.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 6PT 0.05IN 6PT 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	All of the holders of the Company&rsquo;s
	common shares (including Deswell&rsquo;s major shareholders) have equal voting rights with respect to the common shares held. As
	of June 30, 2016, approximately 10 holders of record, who, management believes, held for more than 3,000 beneficial owners, held
	Deswell&rsquo;s common shares. According to information supplied to the Company by its transfer agent, at June 30, 2016, 10 holders
	of record with addresses in the United States held approximately 11.7 million of our outstanding common shares.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: BOLD 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 6PT 0.05IN 6PT 0">
	Related Party Transactions
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 6PT 0.05IN 6PT 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	Deswell had no transactions of
	the kind specified in
<FONT STYLE="FONT-VARIANT: SMALL-CAPS">
	Item
</FONT>
	7.B. of Form 20-F from April 1, 2013 through June 30,
	2016, the latest practical date prior to filing of this Annual Report.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 6PT 0.05IN 6PT 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	Since Deswell completed its initial
	public offering in the United States, it has been Deswell&rsquo;s policy that all transactions between Deswell and any interested
	director or executive officer be approved by a majority of the disinterested directors and be on terms that are no more favorable
	than would be available from an independent third party.
</P>

	2016 aggregating $1,685,905, $561,968 of which was based on results for the last quarter of the

<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 6PT 0.05IN 6PT 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	The Company declared, but did
	not pay, a dividend of $1,123,937 in fiscal 2016, which was based on the results of the last two quarters of the year ended March
	31, 2016. The dividend will be paid in fiscal 2017.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 6PT 0.05IN 6PT 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	Commencing in fiscal year 2017,
	financial results will be released semi-annually, rather than quarterly as in previous fiscal years. Under the new practice, the
	Company expects to pay cash dividends on a semi-annual basis based on the Company&rsquo;s six-month results. Whether future dividends
	will be declared will depend upon the Company&rsquo;s future growth and earnings, of which there can be no assurance, and the Company&rsquo;s
	cash flow needs for future development, which growth, earning or cash flow needs may be adversely affected by one or more of the
	factors discussed in
<FONT STYLE="FONT-VARIANT: SMALL-CAPS">
	Item
</FONT>
	3 &ldquo;Key Information &mdash; Risk Factors.&rdquo; Accordingly,
	there can be no assurance that future cash dividends on the Company&rsquo;s common shares will be declared, what the amounts of
	such dividends will be or whether such dividends, once declared for a specific period will continue for any future period or at
	all.
</P>

<EFX_ADDITIONAL_INFORMATION>
<A NAME="FIS_ADDITIONAL_INFORMATION"></A>
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 12PT 0.05IN 6PT 0">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-VARIANT: SMALL-CAPS">
<B>
	Item
</B>
</FONT>
<B>
	10. ADDITIONAL INFORMATION
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: BOLD 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 6PT 0.05IN 6PT 0">
	Memorandum and Articles of Association
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 6PT 0.05IN 6PT 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	Effective December 13, 2007,
	we amended and restated our Memorandum and Articles of Associations (collectively the &ldquo;2007 Charter&rdquo;), the instruments
	governing a company organized under the law of the BVI, which are comparable in purpose and effect to certificates or articles
	of incorporation and bylaws of corporations organized in a state of the United States.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN: 6PT 0.05IN 6PT 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	Effective March 26, 2010, we
	amended Regulation 6.15 of our Articles of Association to reduce the number of our outstanding common shares that must be present
	in person or by proxy in order to hold any meeting of shareholders from no less than 50 percent to no less than 33&#8531; percent.
</P>
<!-- FIELD: PAGE; SEQUENCE: 46; VALUE: 2 -->

	46

	Under our 2007 Charter, as amended
	through March 26, 2010 and applicable to the date of this Report (&ldquo;our Charter&rdquo;):
</P>

	our shares are eligible for a direct registration system operated by a securities depository
	in accordance with NASDAQ Marketplace Rule 5210(c) (formerly Rule 4350(1)).
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<TABLE CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%" STYLE="FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 6PT">

</TD>
<TD STYLE="PADDING-RIGHT: 0.05IN">
	various consequential amendments were made to our Memorandum and Articles of Association in accordance
	with the advice from our U.S. and BVI counsel so as to (a) be consistent with the BVI Business Companies Act, 2004, as amended
	(the &ldquo;Act&rdquo;), the Act having come into force on January 1, 2004 superseding in certain respects the International Business
	Companies Act, 1984, the relevant legislation which had previously governed us and (b) to make conforming changes resulting from
	the transition of the NASDAQ Stock Market&rsquo;s operations on August 1, 2006 to that of a national securities exchange in the
	United States.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
